Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomized between a perineal or an abdominal approach

Participants.evidence: Patients considered unsuitable for random allocation were only included in randomizations B or C.

Intervention.evidence: Patients in randomization B (perineal group) were randomized to Delorme’s or Altemeier’s procedures and those in randomization C (abdominal group) to suture rectopexy or resection rectopexy.

Objective.evidence: The Swedish Rectal Prolapse Trial was performed with the aim to compare the outcomes after the most common surgical approaches to rectal prolapse.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were bowel function and quality of life, measured using Wexner incontinence score and RAND-36, and secondary outcomes were complications and recurrence at 3 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomized between a perineal or an abdominal approach

Number_Randomised.evidence: During the study period, 134 patients were randomized: 18 in randomization A group, 80 in randomization B group and 54 in randomization C group

Result_Outcome.evidence: Improvements in Wexner and RAND-36 scores were seen but with no significant difference between the groups.

Harms.evidence: There were no significant differences regarding postoperative complications.
